audio_caption: The clip begins with the sound of a car engine starting and idling, creating an ambient background suggestive of a vehicle or garage setting. The engine fades out as a male speaker enthusiastically begins with the claim, "My next car gets 100 miles per gallon," and introduces himself as Joe Justice, a software consultant and member of Team Wiki Speed. In a professional, informative tone, he describes Team Wiki Speed's accomplishment of building a fast, affordable, efficient, and safe commuter car, noting the functional prototype's rapid construction in three months. A brief pause marks a shift to addressing how this is possible, given the slow rate of change in existing car designs, noting a six-year period resulting in only a 2 mile-per-gallon improvement. The speaker attributes this slowness to the high cost of changing manufacturing processes, noting the long investment periods for existing designs. The speaker states that these long development cycles are common in manufacturing teams.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the differences between "old software teams" and "new software teams", noting that "new software teams" run on seven-day development cycles, allowing "changes very quickly." He then mentions the "Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize" of 2008 and a "ten million dollar prize purse" intended to challenge whether building 100-mile-per-gallon cars to "road legal safety specifications" was possible. He mentions that "the closest thing we had in 2008 were like bobsleds," which could achieve the mileage but had one occupant and did not meet legal requirements.

A single male speaker with an enthusiastic and storytelling tone narrates an experience joining the X Prize. He started alone, began blogging, and eventually gathered a team through social networking.  He describes how within three months, they created a car for the X Prize with a volunteer team, and tied for tenth place, surpassing over a hundred other cars.

The clip begins with a single male speaker describing how his team uses techniques with "funny sounding names," like "Agile, Lean, and Scrum" to make changes quickly, his tone is informative. Following this, a distinct "beep" sound effect is heard.

The clip begins with a male speaker sharing an anecdote, recalling an invitation to an auto show following a competition win. He mentions the desire for a more aesthetically pleasing car and the expensive and time-consuming process of creating one. In response, he took time off work to attend composite school. The clip ends with a sound effect, which seems to be a door slamming.

The clip begins with a male speaker resuming a story, detailing the construction of car models and a composite process. He explains that they were able to build their car body in "structural carbon fiber in three days for $800". Laughter and applause follow, then the speaker expresses appreciation, stating, "You guys are awesome. Thanks so much." He continues his narrative, explaining that they were placed on the main floor of an auto show "between Ford and Chevrolet". He describes the car as "beautiful".

The clip starts with a male speaker listing media outlets, including "the Discovery Channel, Popular Science, Popular Mechanics, the New York Times Online, the National Geographic Channel, Wired Magazine, the Forbes Billionaire Club." He continues, explaining that the topics he's discussing happened in a six-month period.

A male speaker describes Rob Moorebacker leading the German town, Maryland team, producing a convertible city car mold. He then explains the car's modular design, with an engine swappable from gasoline to electric as quickly as changing a tire, and a car body switchable from convertible to pickup truck. The speaker speaks clearly and enthusiastically.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing a car chassis, emphasizing its lightness and safety rating. He speaks in a confident and informative tone, followed by applause and appreciative shouts from an audience. He expresses gratitude. He then shifts to discussing safety test designs and a test-driven development process, again met with audience approval. He discusses less stuff being used, detailing how a high school graduate builds a WikiSpeed car with affordable equipment compared to expensive automotive processes. He then discusses reducing costs in tooling, machinery, and complexity, which enables changes to any part of the car every seven days. Lastly, he talks about distributed collaborative teams. The speaker emphasizes that "morality is a multiplier for velocity."

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing how his teams are organized. He mentions it's "the smallest fastest way to organize an agile team," and calls it "Scrum," a method for managing a team in a rapid way. He describes that his teams are managed in "Team Wiki speed."

The clip features a male speaker who discusses a collaborative work environment, stating "we do all our work in pairs" to avoid training and documentation needs. He illustrates this with an example of two colleagues, "Martin Val and Kurt Roy," building an engine together, sharing knowledge in real-time. The overall tone is informative.

The audio begins with a single male speaker describing a workflow visualization process. He emphasizes that the necessary tools are free and recently available, suggesting a novel approach. The speaker believes that nearly every industry benefits from this process, and it may become necessary for businesses to compete in the future. He finishes the statement by asking a rhetorical question, "So what to do?"

The audio features a male speaker offering instructions to different types of listeners: business owners, team members, and process coaches. He suggests tasks tailored to each role, such as identifying a process coach for the business, asking process coaches for efficiency improvements, or identifying a company's value stream map. His tone is encouraging and instructional.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about "WikiSpeed's" next steps. The speaker then provides an overview of their organization, mentioning they have "more than 100 volunteers in eight countries now," and that they "sell cars now." The speaker has a confident and informative speaking tone.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing using processes to "solve bigger problems", specifically mentioning eradicating polio and developing low-cost medical centers for developing communities. He then humorously pauses with a "cough" before continuing to encourage joining Team Wiki Speed to "change the world" and sharpen agile skills. After a short encouragement about making a difference in the world, he invites everyone to spend two hours a day or week rapidly solving problems for social good.

The audio features a single male speaker, sounding enthusiastic. He shares details about Team Wiki Speed, noting that members "spend between two and eight hours a week helping us rapidly develop our cars" with "phenomenal and regular successes". He adds that they "build ultra efficient cars," and the listener "might help eradicate rotavirus or develop simple, maintainable distributed banking applications for the developing world." Then he says, "And that might be even cooler than watching TV or coaching Little League."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that if everyone in the room spent two hours a week rapidly solving problems, it would be "so awesome". He follows this by exclaiming it would be "like a gorilla high-fiving a shark in front of an explosion." The speech is delivered in an energetic and enthusiastic tone. The speaker then says, "Thank you very much," followed by a crescendo of clapping sounds, suggesting applause from an audience.
